doc.str: Analytical method for protein mapping using hydrogen/deuterium exchange

Analytical methods using hydrogen/deuterium exchange are provided which reduce or eliminate the back-exchange of deuterium for hydrogen. The methods, which are useful in protein and peptide mapping, include the steps of (a) providing a peptide or protein comprising a solvent accessible hydrogen; (b) exchanging the solvent accessible hydrogen for a deuterium; (c) separating the peptide or protein with supercritical fluid chromatography; and (d) analyzing by mass spectrometry the mass of the separated peptide or protein. Supercritical fluid chromatography enables the observation of fast exchanging hydrogen atoms missed using conventional liquid chromatography methods.

Wikipedia, Title: "High Performance Liquid Chromatography," Feb. 8, 2006, pp. 1-3. cited by other. | Emmett, et al., "Supercritical Fluid Chromatography Reduction of Hydrogen/Deuterium Back Exchange in Solution-Phase Hydrogen/Deuterium Exchange with mass Spectrometric Anaylysis," Anal. Chem. 78:7058-60 (2006). cited by other . | Wang, et al., "Conformational and Dynamic Chanages of Yersinia Protein Tyrosine Phosphatase Induced by Ligand Binding and Active Site Mutation and Revealed by H/D Exchange and Electrospray Ionization Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry," Biochemistry, 37:15289-99 (1998). cited by other . | Bolanos, Ben, et al., SFC/MS in drug discovery at Pfizer, La Jolla, 2004, International Journal of Mass Spectroetry, vol. 238, pp. 85-97. cited by examiner .
